title: Jennifer Aniston lifts the lid on her recent Friends reunion
text:
Jennifer Aniston has revealed all the Friends cast reunited earlier this week, after she shared a selfie with co-stars Matt LeBlanc and Courteney Cox.

Turns out the whole six of the main characters, including Lisa Kudrow (Phoebe), Matthew Perry (Chandler) and David Schwimmer (Ross), were also present.

After spending the special day itself having a dinner party with Lisa as well as Charlie Puth and Judd Apatow, Courteney (Monica) became host for two more friends – Jennifer Aniston (Rachel) and Matt LeBlanc (Joey).

Underneath, she wrote: ‘A rare night and I love it.’

It wasn’t just the three (or four) of them, though, as Jen lifted the lid on what went down when they all got back in the same room.

‘We had dinner, the whole gang. Everyone was there,’ she told Howard Stern on his SiriusXM radio show this week.

After she was asked whether it was rare for them to all get together, she insisted: ‘It’s just Schwimmer was in town, we all happened to have a window of time, so we all got together.’

She said they all miss the show and spent their evening ‘laughing so hard’ as we all curse the fact we weren’t flies on the wall.

‘We went to Courteney’s. Nobody got naked, it was very civilised. But we just laughed a lot,’ she said, before adding of Friends: ‘We all miss it every day.’

Of course she was asked whether there would be a reunion, 25 years after the show premiered, and while she said she ‘would be nothing without it’, Jen was hesitant to confirm they were getting back together.

‘I honestly think…we would love it…there is an idea if there is a reboot of the show it won’t be even close to as good as what it was. It would ruin it,’ she said, agreeing the legacy of the show was important.

Speaking of the iconic salaries they received – reportedly topping $1million (£818,000) per episode towards the end – Jen spoke about the group of six’s fight for parity.

‘We stood as a solidary unit and asked for equal pay,’ she said.

‘We were leading the charge, ahead of our time.’
